response.answer_text: The UK education system is known to be very flexible and students can choose to study in a way that fits your lifestyle and career plans & goals. The UK is the home to some of the world’s top universities. Every year thousands of students come to UK to pursue their dreams in these universities. Read on to know about the top 100 colleges in UK, benefits of choosing UK over other destinations to study abroad. The Benefits of Studying in the UK · The top colleges in UK are consistently ranked among the best in the world and the qualifications from best colleges in the UK are internationally valued and recognised. · The 5 % of the world’s scientific research is conducted in the UK and it produces 14 % of the world’s most commonly cited papers. · The students in the UK are given lots of flexibility to choose your study area and you can blend the academic and vocational courses of your own choice. · The methodology used to teach and study in the UK encourages students to be more creative and develop out of box thinking. · You can get tailor-made degrees as per our interests. Thus, if you want to really achieve your dreams and get education in the world’s best universities, you should choose one of the below-mentioned top ranking colleges in UK. Choose from the best because the rest will depend upon your choice. List of Top 50 Colleges in UK University of CambridgeUniversity of OxfordImperial College LondonUniversity of St AndrewsDurham UniversityUniversity of WarwickUniversity of ExeterUniversity of SurreyLondon School of EconomicsUniversity College LondonLancaster UniversityUniversity of BathLoughborough UniversityUniversity of LeedsUniversity of YorkUniversity of SouthamptonUniversity of BirminghamUniversity of East AngliaUniversity of SussexUniversity of BristolUniversity of SheffieldUniversity of EdinburghUniversity of KentNewcastle UniversityUniversity of NottinghamUniversity of GlasgowKing's College LondonUniversity of ManchesterUniversity of LeicesterAston UniversityQueen's University BelfastUniversity of ReadingCardiff UniversityQueen Mary, University of LondonUniversity of EssexRoyal Holloway, University of LondonUniversity of DundeeUniversity of LiverpoolHeriot-Watt UniversityUniversity of BuckinghamCity, University of LondonSwansea UniversityKeele UniversitySOAS University of LondonUniversity of AberdeenUniversity of StrathclydeCoventry UniversitySt George's, University of LondonHarper Adams UniversityUniversity of Stirling

Originally Answered: What university should I go to in the UK? That’s a pretty broad question. Most people who go to the university in the UK reach their decision by some combination of the following three factors: What subject do you want to study at university?What universities are you able to gain admission to?What type of university experience are you looking for?For better or worse, most university conversations in the UK seem to start with Oxford and Cambridge. And the orthodox view is that if they teach the course you want, and you are able to get in, then that is where you should go. They cost the same as any other university, but you benefit from a high calibre environment and their unique one-on-one teaching. But, it should be added, some people don’t flourish in the high pressure Oxbridge environment, or hate the Brideshead revisited architecture and traditions. Next people usually consider the wider Russell group. Although they don’t bill themselves as such, this is broadly a group of the ‘better’ universities in the UK. There is quite a lot of them, and between them they teach pretty much any course you could want. So it really then depends upon what kind of university experience you would like - in particular (i)London or not-London, (ii) urban or more rural, and (iii) on a related note, a tighter ‘campus-style’ university (usually found in more rural settings) or spread about (normally in cities). Outside of the Russell group, there are other excellent universities (St Andrews being an obvious example). And there are also other universities which are not as strong overall, but have excellent courses. It really comes down to what it is that you want to study, and is there a university that can teach that subject well. Remember that in the UK you have to commit to your course of study during the application process. Very best of luck.

The first thing to realise is that the most reliable tables to look at for this, as in virtually any other country, are the domestic tables rather than the global tables. Domestic tables have a much greater range of metrics to draw upon. The second thing is to look at performance across multiple tables, not a single table. The UK has three domestic rankings of universities, the Times, the Guardian and the Complete University Guide. The third thing is that you want to look at sustained performance over time, not just a single-year snapshot. So, over the past ten years, the universities with the highest average position across the three domestic rankings are: Cambridge (1.2)Oxford (1.8)St Andrews (4.0)Imperial (5.3)Durham (6.1)LSE (6.5)Warwick (7.7)UCL (8.8)Lancaster (9.6)Bath (9.8)There aren't any particular surprises there – as you'd expect from the way I put this together, these are all universities that have had sustained success across a variety of measures. A major change from what people identified as “top universities” in the late 20th century, however, is that the redbrick civic universities have been replaced by 1960s plate-glass universities. This is reflected in only 7 of the top ten here being members of the Russell Group of large research universities (St Andrews, Lancaster and Bath being the non-members).

The university that: (should meet all the following criteria) Offers your courseAre you seeking a research intensive or teaching intensive university? You rarely have both in a universityDo you agree/comfortable with the course structure?Gives you the space to grow as a personMeets your needs socially (either excellent nightlife/social life or not very social if you're antisocial yourself)Challenging enough for you or perhaps not as challenging, depending on what you aim forOffers flexibility for part time studies or long distance commute to campus or online studies, depending on your situationHow convenient is the location of the campusHow does your particular department in question fare with the rest of the UK? Department rankings are different from university rankingsDoes your university go out of its way to take care of your needs, which may include a disability or some difficult situationSo really, depending on you, your interests and situation, Oxbridge isn't necessarily the best for you. It's really not for everyone. You may find some other university better for you. You need more research and self reflection. P.S. Not saying this to reduce competition to Oxbridge 🤣🤣. Just genuinely pointing out it's not for everyone, that it depends. What's best for me isn't best for you, vice versa.

The University of Oxford, University of Cambridge and the Imperial College of London are highly-ranked universities in the United Kingdom. These are three of the best global universities in the United Kingdom based on ratings from the world's academic community and research performance, according to U.S. News & World Report.The University of Oxford ranks first with a global score of 86.7. It's made up of a central university, 38 colleges and six Permanent Private Halls. Its research includes humanities, mathematics, physical and life sciences, medical sciences and social sciences. It has 19,919 students, including 6,740 international students. The University of Cambridge ranks second with a global score of 86.2. It consists of 31 residential colleges that admit undergraduate and graduate students. There are six schools, including arts and humanities, biological sciences, humanities and social sciences, physical sciences and clinical sciences. There are 18,812 students, including 6,465 international students. The Imperial College of London ranks third with a global score of 80.4. It offers engineering, medicine, natural sciences and a business school. 7,643 of its 15,060 students are international.

Original question: Which is the best university to study in the UK, and why is that? A few questions, in no particular order… Why do you want to go university?What do you want to study at university?What do you want to get out of your time at university (other than a bit of paper with “degree” written on it)?What sort of learning environment do you prefer?What sort of non-curricula things would you like to do during your three or more years at university?What criteria are most important to you when judging your “top 10”?The answers to all of these questions will be different for practically everybody. Some people like big, city universities. Some don’t and prefer small, more intimate institutions. Big can be intimidating. Big can mean that you can be lost in a sea of fellow students. Small can mean a lack of options.Just because a university is great at science does not it will be great at, say, history.You are at university for at least three years. There will be more to life than study. Extra-curricula is important - otherwise you may just get your degree from the Open University.At the end of your study where do you want to go? PhD? Job? What? Check out first destination stats for your institutions based on what you want to do.University rankings are often based on post-grad research rankings. Unless you intend to do research this will be irrelevant to you. The quality of accommodation available to students (and cost) should be much more important to you that what postgrads who you may never meet are doing.In short… don't just take anyone’s “top 10” list. Do some research. Decide for yourself.

I think Robert Munchin is so wrong, Domestic tables in the UK are not the most reliable for measuring the prestige of universities. They are the worst. They are only good for knowing which universities one might be comfortable and happy experiencing because the metric is heavily weighted towards student care, not intellectual power of the university. Any table producing Lancaster or Loughborough as a Top 10 university in the UK is a poor table. Even the UK government will tell you that because they know the universities they rely on and pump money into year after year, and those are the mainly the Golden Triangle, Edinburgh and Manchester, which the Global rankings capture this better. The best universities in the UK are: OxfordCambridgeLSEImperialUCLEdinburghKCLDurhamSt AndrewsWarwick

Oxford and Cambridge are at the top, no matter which subject you want to do — they're going to be the best options. After that, I believe Durham is considered the next best thing. It's impossible to rank all unis into a top 10 list after this, because it depends on what subject you want to study. Russell Group universities are generally the best — Russell Group being essentially our version of America's Ivy League. After that, Redbrick universities are the best, normally these refer to universities which have been active for a long time, but they aren't as old or as prestigious as Russell Group unis. After that, there are ex-polytechnics. So called because in the early 90s/late 80s, many polytechnic schools were converted into unis.

This is a very controversial question. Most prestigious college in what? Engineering, Applied sciences, Literature, History, Art, Natural sciences? Without specifying the subject you want to know about, it would be an anomaly to assign any particular college as prestigious from a bird's eye view. Undoubtedly, Cambridge and Oxford universities are known to be the most esteemed higher education institutions in UK. However, there might be some specific subjects which are not excellent there as compared to some not-so-popular colleges across the UK. Especially, when it comes to research, it would be hard to assign any particular university as prime in all areas. While one might be excellent in electrical engineering, the same might not be quite flourishing in terms of biological sciences.

United Kingdom has some of the leading universities in the world. Students from across the world choose UK's universities for there higher education. Here are few leading universities in UK. University of Cambridge - It is one of the leading universities in the world. The university has various Schools, Departments, Faculties and Colleges that provide excellent learning and research facilities. University of Oxford - It is another leading and one of the oldest universities in the United Kingdom. It's a place that offer excellent teaching, guidance and open various doors of opportunities. London School of Economics and Political Science - LSE has a worldwide academic reputation for providing excellent and quality teaching. It is one of the best universities to study social science. UCL - University College London has consistently ranked among UK's best universities. It's a diverse global community of outstanding students, academics and alumni. Imperial College London - It is renowned for providing best course in science, medicine, engineering and business.

Like so many rankings there is some debate about which ranking is the correct one.   Searching online for _uk university rankings_ will bring up a number of rankings.   It might also be worth looking for _russell group universities_. But here's a story.   When one of my sons left school one of his friends went to a university I'd never heard of and my first thought was to ask we he would go to such a low graded place.   It may have been low graded overall but they offered the best course in the subject he wanted to study and was recognised for that fact.   So, if you're looking to study something specific it's worth finding all the places that offer your subject and looking in to all of them.   You might be surprised.

I did not go to University but both our children did. I was surprised to find that the style and scope of the courses differed a lot and the best University to go to would be the one which fitted your style of learning and scope of the course. They both did Music Degrees and went to Universities offering very different courses. They chose well and are both working in music as a result. One is working for a music publisher and plays and writes music and the other teaches piano and woodwind and also conducts and plays woodwind too. I imagine the same advice, namely choose your course wisely, would be appropriate whatever subject you are going for. Also, and I understand it is not PC to comment on spelling and punctuation but since we are all friends here I feel comfortable adding that the question should have universities in it rather than university since you are referring to a plural.

The most prestigious university in UK would be University of Cambridge. Cambridge University has been recognized as world’s one of the six super brands and the only university from UK to be in this prestigious list. In 2017, Cambridge was ranked the second best in the world. The university has quite a good number of Notable Alumni-from Stephen Hawking, Charles Darwin to Dame Jane Goodall. Cambridge University is known for its science and social science subjects with intensive research going on in science field everyday. Getting admission in Cambridge is extremely difficult with only the best of minds from around the world getting into it.

Imperial College But it really depends what you are looking for. Oxbridge are older and may be a better bet if you want to find yourself a high flying wife or husband. St Andrews may be a better bet to bag a British royal. Agriculture try Reading or RAC. Business try Lancaster, Leeds, Manchester or the LSE (there are more). Distance learning, the OU should be your number one choice. Do you want to live in expansive parkland, then Lancaster, Nottingham or Reading but to be at the heart of a city Manchester, Edinburgh or one of the London colleges may be a better bet.

Top in what?  The answer to any university rating question depends partly on the discipline. I am rather skeptical myself about rankings tables - but if you're into them, the three main global ones generally offer breakdowns by region, by subject, and (at least THE and Shanghai) by country.Times Higher Education World University Rankings 2014-2015QS University Rankings Shanghai  World University Rankings (officially 'Academic Rankings of World Universities'). The Guardian also does an annual UK one. 'Universities' is the usual word in UK and Ireland - 'undergraduate schools' might sound like a contradiction to some people, although of course they'll understand what you mean.

It all depends on what you want to study. At the time I went to university the first time round, the University of Liverpool was ranked about 10th overall, but for the subject I studied, it was higher than both Oxford and Cambridge who are almost always ranked number 1 and number 2. The second time, I went to UEA, which overall was ranked about 15th, but for the subject I studied it was the number 2 University in the country (I personally rank it number 1 because the official number 1 university for it only taught American Literature in their ‘American Studies’ course whereas UEA taught history, politics, and literature). Overall rankings tell you nothing much at all, it's the subject rankings you want to be looking at.

Q: What's the best university in the U.K.? While I’m temped to say Cambridge, the truth is it depends on what you want to study. Teaching and research reputations rise and fall depending on many factors. Personally I think Cambridge is great for experimental psychology, but crap for medicine and good for oriental studies and anthropology. Edinburgh is excellent for dentistry and computer science. Oxford is good for PPE. North Stafford is surprisingly good for computer science and real-time programming and no longer sited next to the crematorium…

I follow QS world ranking as it is the only international ranking to have received International Ranking Expert Group (IREG) approval. QS World University Rankings 2020 QS system comprises the global overall and subject rankings (which name the world's top universities for the study of 48 different subjects and five composite faculty areas), alongside five independent regional tables (Asia, Latin America, Emerging Europe and Central Asia, the Arab Region, and BRICS) Hope this helps.! All the best.!

It would depend entirely on which subject you are studying. For example if you wanted to study Automotive Engineering, Oxford and Cambridge are ruled out anyway as they don't do this subject. In this example Bath or Loughborough are the best bets. So the point is it depends on the subject.

It depends on the subject. But Oxford, Cambridge and Sterling are preferred by the Establishment. Those that don’t get in spend three years at a ‘Russel Group’ varsity like Bristol, Durham, Manchester et al, with a chip on their shoulder, protesting to loudly why they’re so glad they didn’t go to Oxbridge.

My daughter is studying at the University of Edinburgh. It has history, prestige, a good accommodation system and Edinburgh is a lively, attractive, historic and safe city. The Edinburgh fringe and festival is the biggest arts festival in the world and many students get involved with it. With three other universities in the city there are lots of other students too. It’s also not as expensive as London.

I believe, that there is no one prestigious college but a number of them like the university of Oxford, University of Cambridge, Imperial College London, kings College London and I believe all the subsidiary colleges of the University of London and not to forget the university of Edinburgh.

Can you recommend top universities in the UK? Any useful answer to this question will require a lot of personal and specific information. Here is the next best thing. The University of London, which is a federation of a number of Colleges has 101,000 undergraduate and 77,000 post grad students. The Open University has 113,000 undergrads and 9,000 post grads. The University of Manchester with 27,000 undergrads and 13,000 post grads University College London has 20,000 undergrads and 21,000 post grads University of Leeds has 26,000 undergrads and 9,000 post grads and so on: University of Oxford has 15,00 undergrads and 10,500 post Grads University of Cambridge has 12,500 undergrads and 8,000 post grads and finally, coming in at no 168 Gower College has 130 undergrads

Ok so everybody rightly says Cambridge, Oxford and also Imperial College, you should probably add the LSE and, for postgraduate study exclusively including MBA : the London Business School. Cambridge and Oxford are amongst the top four universities in the world.

All across the country but mostly in the big cities. The ones named University of ( Big city name ) are mostly the best. So : University of Edinburgh University of Glasgow University of Manchester University of Birmingham University of London University of Bristol University of Sheffield University of Leeds The very best are University of Oxford, and University of Cambridge; situated in large towns rather than big cities.
The generally accepted top 10 universities in the UK: Cambrige, Oxford Imperial, LSE UCL, Warwick St Andrews, Durham, Bristol, Edinburgh

Sometimes people refer to “Oxbridge,” meaning Oxford and/or Cambridge, but this is not really a category it is a kind of popular way of talking about these very oldest universities.

As in the U.S., the best college is a matter of fit, between what the student wants, needs, and can gain in value and what the school offers. This link should offer a starting point. You should then explore the Websites of those schools that seem to offer a reasonable match for you: Study in the UK

It simply depends on not the uni but the course being offered and how well you get on on that course with the tutors .some top rep universities are simply not good at all courses. You own path may well be better with an underrated uni if the actual course best fits the way you learn. Simply put do proper research on the course students and graduates and NOT the parent uni if you want a course that best fits you
